thread.title: Carwyn Jones and Leanne Wood launch Wales' Brexit plan
thread.title_full: Carwyn Jones and Leanne Wood launch Wales' Brexit plan

title: Carwyn Jones and Leanne Wood launch Wales' Brexit plan

organizations.name: brexit  speaking on sunday politics wales

text:
Carwyn Jones and Leanne Wood launch Wales' Brexit plan   Getty Images The first minister and Plaid Cymru's leader are due to launch their Brexit plan for Wales. 
Carwyn Jones and Leanne Wood, along with the Welsh Liberal Democrats, have said they want to have "continued participation in the single market" . 
The launch on Monday follows a speech last week by Theresa May where she outlined her 12 principles for Brexit . 
Welsh Conservative leader Andrew RT Davies said there was a "disorganised message coming from Wales". 
Writing in the Sunday Times ahead of the launch, Mr Jones and Ms Wood said their Brexit plan was not a "shopping list of demands" but the best way to start negotiations to secure the best deal for Wales. 
The white paper is expected to set out Wales' priorities for immigration, funding and trade ahead of the triggering of Article 50. Row over Plaid Cymru Labour coalition comment after Brexit 
Speaking on Sunday Politics Wales , former MEP Eluned Morgan said her understanding was access to the single market would be the top priority for Welsh party leaders. 
"There needs to be a different approach to immigration, so that if people come here they need to be here with a job, but there's also an understanding that we need people to be helping us with our services," the Labour AM for mid and west Wales added. 
The document follows an agreement between Labour, Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats. 
Welsh Conservative leader Andrew RT Davies said he would have tried to reach a wider cross-party agreement but claimed the first minister had not invited him. 
"We have a disorganised message coming from Wales," he said, adding Europe also needed to respond on the issue of immigration. 
"When the single market was created and the tenets that underpin the single market, this mass movement of people around Europe wasn't a consideration," he said. 
"It is a consideration today." 
The leaders' launch comes ahead of the expected decision by the Supreme Court on Tuesday on whether Parliament should have a say before Article 50 is invoked . Related Topics
